utterances: (As Jill Taylor) Plus nine?
(As Prof. Micky Rosa) No.
(As Ben Campbell) Plus 11?
(As Prof. Micky Rosa) No.
(As Jill Taylor) Dude, I lost count 20 cards ago.
(As Prof. Micky Rosa) Don't call me dude.
Instead of counting cards, Renninger is now betting that he can turn sugarcane into a cheap, clean biofuel.
That's one of the projects being worked on at Amyris Biotechnologies, a company he and some of his post-doc buddies from UC Berkley started five years ago.
The name Amyris, he says, was inspired by a plant that's grown in the West Indies.
It makes an oil that smells a lot like sandalwood oil.
Sandalwood oil's very expensive.
Amyris oil is less expensive.
Amyris, the company, relies on a process called synthetic biology.
They basically hack into microbes and manipulate them in order to produce certain molecules.
Their first mission was to produce artemisinin.
It's a wonder drug traditionally derived from the wormwood plant and used to treat malaria.
But it's pricey.
So what we're doing is producing that drug in a microbe.
Instead of extracting it from a plant, we extract the genes from the plant.
The result: artemisinin that is more than 50 percent cheaper than the traditional version.
Two years ago, Amyris began using that same cell-hacking technology to develop fuel that could power jets and cars.
In their labs on the fourth floor of a generic-looking office building, vacuum pumps churn in time to jazz that plays on the stereo.
Lab technicians here are hard at work engineering different strains of yeast.
So this is the first place we go to test the strain.
Renninger points to a machine that's violently shaking several glass flasks.
Inside each flask is yeast that feeds off a solution of sugar water.
And as they grow, they produce more of themselves, and they produce the compound that we've engineered them to make.
That compound is a hydrocarbon fuel with the same molecular structure found in petroleum-based fuel.
Renninger says their fermented sugar-based biodiesel may be a better option than corn-based ethanol.
When you make ethanol, you have to distill the ethanol.
That's very energy intensive.
When you're making a hydrocarbon, the separation is simplified.
It's like oil and water.
The separation is very easy, which means your impact on global greenhouse gas emissions is actually reduced.
And, Renninger adds, unlike other alternative fuels currently being developed, their biodiesel can power engines already in use, and it can be transported using existing infrastructure.
But right now, there's not a whole lot of their biodiesel.
Renninger says to date, they've increased their yield by 10 million fold, but when you're working in a relatively small lab with one cell at a time, that doesn't add up to much.
We're making on the order of liters to gallons to tens of gallons per batch.
That's about to change, Amyris Biotechnologies recently announced it will partner with a Brazilian company to start commercial production of sugarcane-based biodiesel.
Their goal over the next two years is to be able to produce fuel at $55 to $60 a barrel, a price that will likely look good to consumers.
Just this morning, oil was trading at a record $129 a barrel.
Alex Cohen, NPR News.
So how soon would we be able to fill up on sugarcane-based biodiesel, or any other oil substitute?
Gary Was studies the future of energy.
He's the director of the University of Michigan's Memorial Phoenix Energy Institute.
So, Mr. Was, sugarcane-based biodiesel or corn-based?
Are those the best alternatives out there right now?
They may be the alternatives that are there now, but they're probably not the best.
There are a lot of drawbacks to these types of sources of ethanol.
Corn-based, of course, competes with the food supply.
You need prime agricultural land.
And while ethanol has positives in replacing oil, it also has a very low energy value compared to gasoline.
And part of this causes the economics, or the greenhouse gas advantage, to be very minimal for corn ethanol.
So, you know, you'd want to look towards something like cellulosic as a much better ethanol product down the line.
Is that switchgrass?
That's right.
Well, what else is out there?
What else maybe holds more promise?
One of the most valuable energy forms is electricity.

If you could imagine that we electrify our transportation system - which we're starting to now, we're on the path to do that - then you could actually use electricity generation not only for powering homes and businesses, but also for powering transportation.
We're experimenting with hybrid cars around the world.
Very soon we'll see plug-in hybrid electrics, which will extend the range to maybe 40 miles on a charge.
And you should be able to plug these into your wall socket in your garage.
And then beyond that, we may be seeing the full electric vehicle.
So this really is a major transformation that's just beginning right now.

One of the reasons it's so attractive is because you not only reduce your dependence on oil, which is a big problem, but you also give yourself the opportunity to attack the greenhouse gas issue if you start looking at the front end, how we generate electricity and can replace that with renewables or nuclear energy, instead of coal.
So we'd have to figure out how to produce that electricity cleanly.
That's right.
People talk about alternative energy, and I think they generally mean renewables when they say that.
But you have to keep nuclear energy in that mix as well, because it's frankly our only proven major electricity producer, outside of coal.
How far away are we from having a lot of our gasoline needs met by electricity?
Oh, we're a long ways.
This is a cold reality.
These things are going to take a lot of time.
Well, what would you suggest in the interim?
It depends on which evil you're trying to fix.
In the energy world, I see two evils.
One is, we're overdependent on oil as an energy source.
And second, we are toying with changing our climate dramatically by the production of greenhouse gases.
Now if you fix the greenhouse gas problem, you're going to end up fixing the oil problem because oil is a major source of greenhouse gases, about a third of them.
You can approach the oil problem without solving the greenhouse gas problem.
So assuming you want to do both, one of the things that we need to do in the interim is figure out how to manage carbon.
Because we are going to, most probably, use all the oil that's available to us, and a lot of coal, while we try and figure out how to make these cleaner technologies economical and large-scale.
Gary Was is director of the University of Michigan's Memorial Phoenix Energy Institute.
He looks at the future of energy.
Thank you.
(SOUNDBITE OF PROTEST)

Two years ago, the multiple Pulitzer Prize winner set out his views on globalization in a widely acclaimed book called, ""The World is Flat."" In it, he argued that the playing field had become leveled, or flat, for countries like China and India to compete and about the ways the United States could thrive in the globalized economy.

Today, a new edition of ""The World is Flat"" is out in paperback with two new chapters that address how to be a political activist in a flat world and how to manage your privacy in an increasingly public world.
Tom Friedman joins us in just a moment.
Later in the program, Rock Harper, the chef who emerged from ""Hell's Kitchen"" on television last night, and your letters.
But first, a conversation with Tom Friedman.
If you have questions for him about Iraq, globalization, the Middle East or oil, give us a call.
Our number here in Washington is 800-989-8255.
That's 800-989-TALK.
E-mail - talk@npr.org.
And you can join the conversation on our blog.
That's at npr.org/blogofthenation.
Tom Friedman joins us here in Studio 3.
Nice to have you back on the program.
Well, thank you.
On Iraq, we've read a series of cautiously optimistic assessments of the so-called surge, on the military side at least…
Yeah.
…from recent visitors to Iraq.
I know you're on your way to Baghdad soon.
What do you expect to find?

Well, I'm going because I want to make my own assessment obviously, but I'm also going with enormous humility in the sense that - you know, one things that has always struck me about Iraq, this will be my, I guess, my sixth visit, compared to covering Lebanon.
I covered Lebanon during the Civil War from '79 to '84.
And reporters in Lebanon, Neal, we can go north, south, east, west.
We can go the Christian side in the morning and the Palestinian side in the afternoon, the Shiites in the evening, and the Sunnis the next morning, and the Druze, you know, for tea.
And as a result of that, after a couple of years in Lebanon, if you were there and halfway decent reporter, you could feel like you had a bird's eye view of the country.
In fact, I would say reporters in Lebanon had the best bird's eye view.
In Iraq, that's not the case.
The thing that's always struck me about Iraq is no one has a bird's eye view of the country.
Everyone has to look at it through a peephole.
That said, my own metric on whether the surge is working or not - the surge is not working, I think of surges in Iraq the way I think of Arab-Israeli peace overtures.
And I have a fundamental rule about Arab-Israeli peace overtures, and it goes like this.
If you need a Middle East expert to explain it to you, it's not real, okay?
No one had to explain Anwar Sadat's trip to Jerusalem.
Everyone got it in their gut.

Yet everyone had to explain the Saudi peace overture, which, actually, I was involved in, and - because it was basically facts, you know, to the Israeli people, so some of them didn't interpret, you know, the facts.
I kind of feel that way about the surge.
That is - if it needs a Middle East expert to explain to you why it's working, then it's not working.
Because to me, the measure of the surge working is not whether, you know, the number of people, you know, turning up dead in Diyala province is down by 30 percent.
All that tells you, Neal, is that where you put more American troops, you get more security.
Well, we knew that from before.
The measure of the surge working is, is there an Iraq.

Because is there an Iraqi state with an Iraqi army to hand over those places where large number of American troops can establish security to an Iraqi army that would report to a unified Iraqi government?
That strikes me as still a very much open question.
Another open question is the patience of the American people.
And that is an evaluation.
Well, we keep hearing, you know, there's a military timetable, there's a political timetable, and there's also a public timetable, and patience has run out.
